metadata./Title: A case of a child with anterior blepharitis caused by Candida albicans: a case report

sections.Background:
Background To date, there have been few detailed reports of the clinical findings in cases of fungal blepharitis. In 
this report, we present a rare case of anterior blepharitis in a Japanese child in whom Candida albicans was identified 
from secretions on the eyelash roots and present the clinical findings of the patient’s eyelid margin via photograph 
documentation.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation This study involved a 6-year-old Japanese boy with Treacher–Collins syndrome and severe ulcerative colitis who, during a follow-up visit at the Department of Pediatrics at Osaka Medical and Pharmaceutical Univer sity Hospital, Takatsuki City, Osaka, Japan, suffered a cardiac arrest due to massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage, which 
led to persistent altered consciousness following resuscitation. Subsequently, the patient developed lagophthalmos, 
resulting in corneal ulcers caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, which were successfully treated 
with a six-times-daily administration of 1% vancomycin ophthalmic ointment. Thereafter, the patient underwent a sixtimes-daily administration of ofloxacin ophthalmic ointment for the treatment of lagophthalmos keratitis. However, 
increased ocular discharge, upper eyelid edema, redness of the eyelash roots, and eyelash loss (madarosis) developed 
in his left eye, leading to a diagnosis of anterior blepharitis. Smear and culture tests of the eyelash root secretions 
revealed the presence of Candida albicans. The patient was then treated with a six-times-daily administered 1% pimaricin ophthalmic ointment, resulting in rapid resolution of the blepharitis and subsequent regrowth of the eyelashes.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion In this study, we report the clinical findings of a rare case of fungal anterior blepharitis in a Japanese 
child in which Candida albicans was identified. A noticeable white discharge at the base of the eyelashes and some what rapid eyelash loss were characteristic symptoms.
Keywords  Anterior blepharitis, Fungal blepharitis, Candida albicans, Case report
Background
In Japan, blepharitis is classified as blepharitis and eyelid 
dermatitis on the basis of its anatomical location, and is 
further classified into anterior blepharitis and posterior 
blepharitis, with posterior blepharitis often accompanied by meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD). Anterior 
blepharitis can be classified into infectious and noninfec tious blepharitis, depending on the cause. Staphylococ cus is considered the most common cause of infectious 
blepharitis [1–3]; however, there are few reports of infec tious blepharitis in which fungi have been identified, and 
no detailed findings have been documented for fungal 
blepharitis affecting the eyelid margin.
Herein we present a rare case of anterior blepharitis in 
a Japanese child in which Candida albicans was identi fied in eyelash root secretions. His symptoms included 
a somewhat rapid increase in eye discharge, promi nent white secretion at the base of the eyelashes, and a Open Access

Case presentation
This study involved a 6-year-old Japanese boy with 
Treacher–Collins syndrome (TCS) and severe ulcera tive colitis who was being followed at the Department of 
Pediatrics, Osaka Medical and Pharmaceutical University 
Hospital, Takatsuki City, Osaka, Japan. He had the dis tinctive facial characteristics of TCS, with slanting of the 
palpebral fissures, but there were no colobomas of the 
lower eyelids and a lack of eyelashes. In addition, there 
was no history of lagophthalmic keratoconjunctivitis.
The patient suddenly experienced a cardiac arrest one 
day due to a massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage, fol lowed by a persistent disturbance of consciousness that 
developed after he was resuscitated. Around that same 
time, bilateral conjunctival hyperemia was observed, so 
the patient was referred to the Department of Ophthal mology at our hospital. Upon initial examination at our 
department, conjunctival hyperemia and corneal infil tration below the center of the cornea resembling a ring ulcer were observed in the right eye (Fig.  1a), accompa nied by an epithelial defect and thinning in the center 
(Fig.  1b). In his left eye, conjunctival hyperemia and 
superficial punctate keratopathy (SPK) were observed in 
the lower region of the cornea (Fig.  1c, d). The posterior 
segments of both eyes were unremarkable. Thus, he was 
diagnosed with bilateral lagophthalmic keratoconjuncti vitis and an infectious corneal ulcer in the right eye. For 
treatment, a six-times-daily administration of 0.3% oflox acin ophthalmic ointment was initiated in his right eye. 
However, on the fourth day, the cornea in the area where 
it had thinned was perforated, and anterior chamber 
became flat. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus 
(MRSA) was detected via a culture of a corneal scrap ing, and 1% vancomycin eye ointment was administered 
six times daily. On day 19, the corneal perforation in the 
right eye closed, and the anterior chamber reformed. 
The corneal ulcer then became scarred. Subsequently, 
the patient had to continue using ofloxacin ophthalmic 
ointment for lagophthalmic keratoconjunctivitis in both 
eyes, but 8 months later, the amount of ocular discharge 
from the left eye increased. The attending pediatrician

performed smear and culture tests of the ocular discharge 
from the left eye, and C. albicans was detected. Obstruc tive MGD in the left eye, upper eyelid edema, redness of 
the eyelash roots, and eyelash loss were observed, and 
he was subsequently diagnosed with anterior blepharitis 
(Fig.  2a, b). We observed white secretions clinging to the 
eyelash roots (Fig.  3a), so the secretions were collected; 
another smear and culture test was performed, and C. 
albicans  was detected. Thus, the patient was diagnosed 
with fungal blepharitis, so 1% pimaricin ophthalmic oint ment was then administered six times daily to the eye lash roots of the left eye for 2 weeks. Within 2 weeks after 
the initiation of the treatment, the blepharitis rapidly 
improved. The right eye still had residual corneal opacity, 
yet the anterior eyelid margin of the left eye was clean, 
and despite some irregularities in the alignment, eyelash 
regeneration was observed (Fig.  3b). C. albicans was not 
detected in smear and culture tests conducted 2 months 
later. Due to the presence of lagophthalmic keratocon junctivitis in both eyes, we continued to closely follow 
the patient with regular follow-up examinations until the 
very unfortunate outcome of his death, yet no recurrence 
was noted during that period. Ultimately, the patient died 
without regaining consciousness, and his final visual acu ity could not be determined.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Herein we report a rare case of anterior blepharitis in 
a Japanese child with C. albicans infection. Anterior 
blepharitis, that is, inflammation of the eyelashes and 
follicles, is usually infectious. Staphylococcus aureus 
is the most common organism responsible in infec tious blepharitis [1, 2], along with Propionibacte rium , Corynebacterium, and Moraxella [3]. Infectious 
blepharitis is characterized by hyperemia, edema, and 
telangiectasia of the anterior lid margin, with scaling 
and collarettes visible at the base of the lash follicle. In 
severe chronic cases, poliosis, madarosis, eyelid hyper trophy, or corneal scarring can occur [4]. Moreover, in 
previous reports on pediatric blepharoconjunctivitis, S. 
aureus [5], coagulase-negative staphylococci, and Propionibacterium acnes have been detected [6, 7]. How ever, there have been few reports on the involvement of 
fungi in blepharitis in adults and children. In contrast, 
among noninfectious anterior blepharitis cases, the pres ence of a yeast-like fungus, Pityrosporum orbiculare, has

been reported locally in seborrheic blepharitis [8], but it 
is reported to be nonpathogenic. Moreover, it has been 
reported that, among 21 patients with ulcerative blephar itis associated with atopic dermatitis whose eyelashes 
were regularly covered with hardened crusts and thick 
matted crusts, 19 showed growth of Candida species [9], 
and that fungi was detected in 78.9% of the patients with 
chronic anterior blepharitis with eyelid notching, scar ring, trichiasis, and eyelash loss via periodic acid–Schiff  
staining of the eyelashes [10]. Clinical case reports of 
patients with seborrheic blepharitis with pityriasis alba 
scales appearing on the margin of the lower eyelid treated 
with oral itraconazole have also been documented [11]. 
These findings suggest that, in patients with atopic der matitis and chronic blepharitis, higher rates of fungal 
detection may occur on bacteriological examinations of 
the anterior lid margin or eyelashes. However, the symp toms in our case were different from those in the previ ous study, and to the best of our knowledge, this is the 
first reported clinical course in a case of relatively acute 
fungal blepharitis, as there have been no similar detailed 
reports. It should be noted that our case was also charac terized by a history of MRSA corneal ulcers and lagoph thalmic keratoconjunctivitis, followed by a rapid increase 
in eye discharge and the appearance of noticeable white 
secretions of the eyelash root. He had rapid eyelash 
loss, but the inflammation subsided, and his eyelashes 
regenerated in approximately 2 weeks after applying 1% 
pimaricin ophthalmic ointment to the eyelash roots. 
The patient’s background specifics included TCS, severe 
ulcerative colitis, persistent impaired consciousness, a 
history of lagophthalmic keratoconjunctivitis, and MRSA 
corneal infection. And, quite notably, the patient’s per sistent impaired consciousness may have contributed to 
recurrent urinary tract and respiratory infections, poten tially leading to the development of an abnormal bacte rial flora in the eyelid margin, similar to that observed 
in patients with atopic dermatitis or chronic refractory 
blepharitis.
It is also important to note the characteristic symptoms 
observed in this case, such as the pronounced white dis charge and the eyelash dropout, which may be indicative 
of anterior fungal blepharitis. It is our hope that, in the 
future, the clinical course of fungal blepharitis will be 
more fully elucidated via the examination of additional 
cases.
Conclusions
We report a rare case of a Japanese child with anterior 
blepharitis caused by C. albicans after healing an MRSA 
corneal ulcer that was successfully treated with antifun gal ointment. The patient’s case was characterized by a noticeable white discharge at the base of the eyelashes 
and somewhat rapid eyelash loss.
